title: Provides grants to households for home energy assistance; appropriation
summary: Provides grants of up to $200 to low income households for home energy assistance through the office of temporary and disability assistance; appropriates $500 million therefor.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1734

TITLE OF BILL:

An act
to create the temporary home energy assistance grant program;
making an appropriation therefor;
and
providing for the repeal of such provisions
upon expiration thereof

PURPOSE:

Creates the temporary home energy assistance program, to provide
additional benefits to those who receive federal home-energy
assistance, as well as to provide benefits to those whose incomes
make them ineligible for the federal program.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:

Section 1 creates the temporary home energy assistance grant program,
and outlines the grant limits. Section 2 provides that all those who
are eligible for the federal program and pay for their own heat, will
receive a state grant of $200. Those who pay indirectly for their
heat will receive a state grant of $100. Households that are
ineligible for federal energy assistance, but whose incomes are still
below 100% of the state's median income level, based on size, will
receive a state grant of between $50-$150. Those who pay directly for
their heat and whose income is above 60% but below 75% of the state
median income will receive $150; those whose income is above 75% but
below 85% of the state median income will receive $100; those whose
income is above 85% but below 100% of the state median income will
receive $50. Those who pay indirectly for their heat, and whose
income is between 60% and 100% of the state's median income will
receive $50. This legislation also provides that the grants issued by
this bill will not be considered in any way as income or resources.
Section 3 provides for an immediate effective date, and a sunset of
May 31, 2012.

EXISTING LAW:

Currently, only those whose incomes are less than 60% of the state's
median income, based on household size, are eligible for the home
energy assistance program.

JUSTIFICATION:

Over the past year, fuel prices have been steadily climbing. Increased
demand for oil, coupled with the crippling effects of Hurricane Katrina
has placed an enormous economic burden on consumers. The sharp
increase in petroleum costs will result in much higher heating bills

this winter for all New Yorkers. According to state energy officials,
the cost of natural gas is expected to be up 32% from last winter,
heating oil 31%, propane 21% and electricity 11%. A recent analysis
by federal officials predicts that the average New York family will
have to spend $400 more to heat their home this winter. The
anticipated spike in home heating costs has placed New York State in
the throes of an energy crisis. Many working families and vulnerable
populations will be forced to choose between eating and heating their
homes. This issue was recently highlighted in an article in the New
York Times on 11/27/05; which commented that many offices are not
only seeing an increase in first time applications for assistance,
but are having to refuse assistance to many because they are over the
income limits. This legislation will help ease the burden of this
winter's energy bills, not only for those who already receive
assistance, but for those whose incomes are too high to get the
federal assistance, yet are barely making it by.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:

2010: S.2469 Referred to Finance
2008: S.2484 Referred to Finance
2006: S.7106 Referred to Finance

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:

$500 million appropriation to be made to the program.

EFFECTIVE DATE:

Takes effect immediately and shall expire and be deemed repealed on
May 31, 2012.
